This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Sinding. Sinding is a regretful werewolf prisoner, who is located at a prison.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to take the Ring of Hircine back to Hircine.
The player should first hunt down the beast to draw out Hircine to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: these woods.
The following characters are related to this quest: Hircine, Lord of the Hunt (the god of hunting and monsters).
The following items are related to this quest: Ring of Hircine (a ring that is supposed to control a werewolf's transformations, a relic of Hircine).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Sinding killed a little girl, because he lost control of his transformations. Hircine cursed the Ring of Hircine when Sinding obtained it: it transforms him at the worst of times. Sinding will escape from the prison after giving the quest.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Come to gawk at the monster?
A little girl is dead because of me. Believe me, it wasn't anything I ever intended to do. I just... lost control. I tried to tell them, but none of them believe me.
It's all on account of this blasted ring. This is the Ring of Hircine. I was told it could let me control my transformations. Perhaps it used to. But I'll never know. Hircine didn't care for my taking it, and threw a curse on it. I put it on... and the changes just came to me. I could never guess when. It would be at the worst times. Like... with the little girl.
I don't suppose there's a point in keeping the secret if I'm going to die in here anyway. I'm sure you've heard of men who shift to beasts under the influence of the moons. I am one of them. A werewolf. It's my secret, and my shame. That's why I wanted the ring... it was said to give men like me control. Now I may look like a man, but I still feel the animal inside of me, as strong as ever.
You would take the ring back to Hircine? Oh my. You would do this for me? Here, take it. I don't want anything to do with this wretched thing anymore. Seek out the beast. He wanders these woods. Bring him down and... well, the Lord of the Hunt should smile on you and appear before you.
I wish you luck, but should leave here while I still have my skin. Should our paths cross again, I will remember your kindness. Farewell."
<|endoftext|>

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Orthus Endario. Orthus Endario is an employee of the East Empire Company, who is located at East Empire Company's rundown offices in Windhelm.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to help Orthus Endario prove that the Shatter-Shields are in league with pirates.
The player should first steal Suvaris Atheron's logbook and bring it to Orthus Endario to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Windhelm, a city.
The following characters are related to this quest: Suvaris Atheron (a female dark elf, and the meticulous overseer of the Shatter-Shields' shipping operation, located at Windhelm).
The following groups are related to this quest: East Empire Company (an eastern merchant organization), Shatter-Shields (a powerful family in Windhelm that run a private shipping operation at the docks).
The following locations are related to this quest: Hammerfell (a realm), Vvardenfell (an island).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Pirates have been raiding all along the coast, from Hammerfell to Vvardenfell: the East Empire Company's security forces are limited, and all the mercenaries are tied up in the war.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Sad, isn't it? We can't afford to keep the place running since these attacks started. Pirates, you see. Raiding all along the coast, from Hammerfell to Vvardenfell.
Our own security forces are limited, and all the mercenaries are tied up in this ridiculous war. We don't even know their base of operations, and attacking single ships won't really solve the problem.
Only the Shatter-Shields appear safe. They are a very powerful family here in Windhelm. They run a private shipping operation, and would love to have the docks to themselves. Wouldn't surprise me if they were in league with the pirates, somehow.
Not yet, no. But perhaps an intrepid person such as yourself could help with that. They have a dark elf who oversees their operations. Suvaris Atheron. She's meticulous to a fault, and keeps a logbook with every transaction she makes.
If you get me the logbook, I'll have proof of Shatter-Shield's treachery."

The following characters are related to this quest: Arn (an old male warrior, and a close friend of Olfrid Battle-Born, located at Whiterun).
The following groups are related to this quest: Thieves Guild (a guild of thieves).
The following locations are related to this quest: Solitude (a city), Whiterun (a city), Dragonsreach (the Jarl's palace in Whiterun).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player is a member of the Thieves Guild: the player was sent to do a job for Olfrid Battle-Born. Arn fled from Solitude to Whiterun, but was arrested for drunken behavior. The letter and the prison registry are inside : visitors are not allowed to enter them. Olfrid Battle-Born can't help the player if the player gets caught.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"You're here! And not a moment too soon. If anything should happen to Arn, there'll be hell to pay.
Arn's a close friend of mine. We fought together on the battlefield for many years until old age got the better of us. Now it's up to me to save him one more time... this time from the executioner's block in Solitude.
The city guard in Solitude is seeking Arn for a serious crime. When he fled here, he was arrested for drunken behavior. Can you imagine? Fortunately, his identity isn't known to the authorities in Whiterun, so there's still a chance to save him.
The job is two-fold. First, steal a letter that was sent from Solitude warning Whiterun's guard to be on the lookout for Arn. The second is to change Arn's name in the prison registry to his new identity.
The job is relatively difficult. If it was easy, I would have hired a local thug instead of a professional from the Thieves Guild. You see both of these items are kept inside Dragonsreach, and they don't allow visitors inside the Jarl's or the Steward's chambers.
One more thing. If you get caught, I can't afford to be connected to you. Remember that before you do anything stupid."
<|endoftext|>

The only good bard is a dead one, as far as I'm concerned. All that singing and... mirth."

The player should first find a way into the Temple of Miraak with Frea to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Temple of Miraak, a temple.
The following characters are related to this quest: Storn (the shaman of the Skaal, and Frea's father), Miraak (an ancient, evil man, located at Solstheim).
The following groups are related to this quest: Skaal (a tribe of trusting and hospitable people on Solstheim).
The following locations are related to this quest: Solstheim (an island).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Something has taken control of most of the people of Solstheim, including the Skaal: it makes them work on horrible creations that corrupt the stones. Storn says that Miraak has returned to Solstheim, but that is impossible.

If you want to know what lies beneath the Temple of Miraak, then let us go together. First, we need to find a way into the Temple of Miraak."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Kodlak Whitemane. Kodlak Whitemane is the player's guildleader in the Companions, and a Nord who wants to end up in Sovngarde.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to claim the head of a Glenmoril Witch so that Kodlak Whitemane can cure the Companions' lycanthropy.
The player should first seek out the Glenmoril witches, kill them, and collect their heads to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Glenmoril coven in the wilderness.
The following characters are related to this quest: Hircine (the god of the werewolves, claims dead werewolves in the Hunting Grounds).
The following groups are related to this quest: Companions (a band of honorable warriors cursed with lycanthropy), Glenmoril (a coven of witches).
The following locations are related to this quest: Sovngarde (the storied afterlife of heroic Nords), Hunting Grounds (Hircine's realm, a place where the player can hunt forever).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The Companions are nearly five thousand years old: the Companions became werewolves a few hundred years ago when the Glenmoril witches promised to grant the Companions great power in exchange for hunting their lord Hircine. The Companions were deceived: lycanthropy affects not just the Companions' bodies, but the Companions' spirits as well.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Have you heard the story of how we came to be werewolves?
The Companions are nearly five thousand years old. This matter of beastblood has only troubled us for a few hundred. One of my predecessors was a good, but short-sighted man. He made a bargain with the witches of Glenmoril Coven. If the Companions would hunt in the name of their lord, Hircine, we would be granted great power.
The Companions of old became werewolves. They did not believe the change would be permanent. The witches offered payment, like anyone else. But we had been deceived. The disease, you see, affects not just our bodies. It seeps into the spirit. Upon death, werewolves are claimed by Hircine for his Hunting Grounds. For some, this is a paradise. They want nothing more than to chase prey with their master for eternity. And that is their choice. But I am still a true Nord. And I wish for Sovngarde as my spirit home.
I've spent my twilight years trying to find a cure myself. And now I've found the answer. The witches' magic ensnared us, and only their magic can release us. They won't give it willingly, but we can extract their foul powers by force. I want you to seek them out. Go to their coven in the wilderness. Strike them down as a true warrior of the wild. And bring me their heads. The seat of their abilities. From there, we may begin to undo centuries of impurity."
<|endoftext|>

The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Tharstan will pay the player.
The following locations are related to this quest: Vahlok's Tomb (an old, undiscovered tomb), Solstheim (an island that is covered with ancient ruins), Red Mountain (an active volcano).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The passage to Vahlok's Tomb must have been opened by an earthquake that accompanied one of the Red Mountain's eruptions.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Yes, I think you're just the adventurous sort I need. I have a job offer for you.
As a scholar of history, I've always found Solstheim to be most intriguing. I've made many forays into the ancient ruins that cover the island. I've come to know those ruins so well, I could draw you a map from memory. That's why I noticed the new passage the moment I laid eyes on it.
it leads to an old tomb, I think. It must have been opened by an earthquake that accompanied one of the Red Mountain's eruptions. I'd love to have a closer look, but those old ruins can be dangerous and I'm no adventurer. I'll pay you to watch my back down there.
I'll be heading back there soon. If you're interested, meet me at the ruins and we'll see what we can find. Now I'm off to pack for the expedition!"

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to remove the Summerset Shadows from the picture, and return Torsten Cruel-Sea's silver locket to him.
The player should first find information about the Summerset Shadows to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Niranye's house in Windhelm.
The following characters are related to this quest: Fjotli (Torsten Cruel-Sea's daughter, who liked wearing a lot of jewelry), Niranye (a woman affiliated with the Summerset Shadows, located at Windhelm).
The following groups are related to this quest: Summerset Shadows (a new guild of Altmer thieves, rivals to the Thieves Guild), Altmer (a race of elves), Thieves Guild (a guild of thieves who condemn murder).
The following locations are related to this quest: Windhelm (a city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player is a member of the Thieves Guild. Fjotli was robbed and murdered: Torsten Cruel-Sea tracked down the murderer, a member of the Summerset Shadows, and killed him.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"My daughter Fjotli... she was murdered a few months ago. Left her laying on the ground in a pool of her own blood. I assume they were after her valuables... she always wore far too much jewelry in public. When I told her it'd be the death of her, I never thought...
No need to explain, I'm well aware of your Guild's methods do not include killing. It took me weeks, but I finally tracked down the killer. A bloody Altmer at that. Can you imagine? Let's just say I'm a firm believer in an eye for an eye and leave it at that.
The killer fancied himself a thief in some sort of a new Guild forming around here. Gave me some valuable information before... well, you know. Well, I think we can help each other. You recover what I'm looking for and take out a rival Guild in the process. One of the pieces stolen from Fjotli was a silver locket, a Cruel-Sea family heirloom. I want it back.
The only name I have is Niranye. Has a house right here in Windhelm. That's where you should begin looking."

There are some important facts concerning this quest. Susanna and other two girls were killed the same way: stabbed and cut apart with a blade. There's a war: no one has time to spend on murder investigations.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Another girl killed. The victim is Susanna, from Candlehearth Hall. Served me a drink just a few nights ago... but I can't say I knew her.
She was killed the same way as the other two girls. Looks like she was stabbed, and then cut apart. It's like an animal got to her, but these are the wounds of a blade.
You could help us with the investigation. We're stretched thin as it is with the war. Nobody has the time to spend on this. Not pleasant, but it's the truth.
Here are some starting points for you. I noticed a trail of blood leading away from here. Helgird's taken Susanna's body into the Hall of the Dead to prepare for burial. She's a little crazy, but if she knows anything, it's dead bodies."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is the bandit leader, a paranoid man, giving quest via "Bandit Leader's Journal".
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to find the bandit leader's stash by the old tree stump.
The player should first go to the island to the south and find the old tree stump to complete their objective.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: the bandit leader's stash.
The following characters are related to this quest: Herd (a male bandit in the bandit leader's gang, hates Brodir), Brodir (a male bandit in the bandit leader's gang, hates Herd).
The following items are related to this quest: "Bandit Leader's Journal" (a journal written by the bandit leader).
The following locations are related to this quest: Dragon Bridge (a town).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The bandit leader thinks that his men are going to mutiny: Herd and Brodir are leading their own cliques within the bandits. The bandit leader is going to gather up gold and escape downriver to Dragon Bridge.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Bandit Leader's Journal

5th of First Seed, 4E 201
Idiots! Brodir and Herd were at each others' throats again today, and nearly came to blows. The whole camp is on edge. I've ordered an extra ration of mead, but unless this fighting stops, we'll tear ourselves apart.

11th of First Seed, 4E 201
Rumor is that Herd's gathering followers for a mutiny. Brodir's not stupid; he's probably doing the same, just for insurance. I'd kill them both myself, but the camp's split right down the middle. If I tried, there'd be a knife in my back within a week.
I can't take this anymore. I've begun skimming a little gold from the take, bringing it down here when I can. If I can scrape enough together, I'll make a run for it, head downriver to Dragon Bridge.

28th of First Seed, 4E 201
Brodir's getting suspicious -- I caught him poking around in the cove this afternoon. I don't think he found my stash, but it's not safe here. I took the boat out tonight and stowed it on the island to the south, by the old tree stump.
Had a good haul this week. Another caravan or two and I can finally get out of here, and not a moment too soon."
<|endoftext|>

The crown is made from the bones and teeth of ancient dragons, and it is said to contain a portion of the power of every king who has worn it. True or not, who would dare deny Ulfric's claim, when the legendary Jagged Crown sits upon his brow?
We're headed to Korvanjund. But, if old King Borgas is indeed buried there, we're bound to run into trouble of some kind. Your fellow Stormcloaks are already assembling outside the tomb. I'll meet you there as soon as I'm finished up here."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Brynjolf. Brynjolf is the player's superior in the Thieves Guild.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to teach Aringoth a lesson.
The player should first burn down three bee hives without burning the whole Goldenglow Estate down, and clear out the safe in the main house of the Goldenglow Estate to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Goldenglow Estate, a bee farm.
The following characters are related to this quest: Aringoth (an arrogant wood elf man who owns the Goldenglow Estate, located at Goldenglow Estate), Maven (a powerful woman with criminal connections), Mercer (the man who leads the Thieves Guild).
The following groups are related to this quest: Thieves Guild (a guild of thieves).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The Thieves Guild had an arrangement with Maven: the Thieves Guild kept an eye on Goldenglow Estate to make sure the honey kept flowing, and Maven allowed the Thieves Guild to extort Aringoth and bring in a huge payout. Aringoth stopped sending the Thieves Guild extortion money: Mercer was angry. The player may kill Aringoth, but Maven would prefer him alive.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Goldenglow Estate is a bee farm; they raise the wretched little things for honey. It's owned by some smart-mouth wood elf named Aringoth.
We had an arrangement with Maven. We kept an eye on Goldenglow Estate to make sure the honey kept flowing. In return, Maven allowed us to extort Aringoth and bring in a huge payout.
Goldenglow Estate brought in a mountain of gold for the Guild. You could almost call it our sweetest deal. Then out of the clear blue, Aringoth stops sending us our cut. Mercer was... well, angry to put it kindly.
We need you to teach Aringoth a lesson by burning down three of the estate's hives and clearing out the safe in the main house. The catch is that you can't burn the whole place to the ground. Maven would be furious if you did. She also prefers that Aringoth remains alive, but if he tries to stop you from getting the job done, kill him.
The Guild has a lot riding on this. Don't make me look foolish by mucking it up."

"All I can think about is my son, my Thorald... they say that he was killed, but I know better. I know my son is alive! Those Battle-Borns... they're in with the Imperials. They know it too, and yet they lie to my very face!
It's not wise to discuss how I know about their lies here. Please, if you truly wish to help, meet me at my home. I'll tell you the whole story."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to stop Potema from returning to the living.
The player should first 1) find Potema's skeleton and remove it from the catacombs to complete their objective. These tasks can be completed in the following locations: 1) Potema's Catacombs(catacombs filled with Potema's undead minions).
The following characters are related to this quest: Potema, the Wolf Queen (a former queen of Solitude, and one of the most dangerous necromancers in recorded history, located at Potema's Catacombs), Arkay (the god of life and death).
The following locations are related to this quest: Solitude (a large city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Potema was responsible for the Empire's near collapse almost five hundred years ago: Styrr has a book about Potema. One of Potema's servants busted through a wall into the Temple of Divines. The player was there when Potema was summoned in spirit form. Styrr helps the player with Potema's minions.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Ah Potema, the Wolf Queen. Former queen of Solitude and one of the most dangerous necromancers in recorded history. She was responsible for the Empire's near collapse almost five hundred years ago. I believe I have a book about her...
And now Potema has been summoned in spirit form. Summoned in spirit form is not raised from the dead. She'll need help before she can return to the living.
For the moment, the Wolf Queen has retreated to a place filled with dead eager to serve her. She has gone to her old Catacombs. A few days ago, one of her servants busted through a wall into the Temple of Divines. We'll need you to go into the Catacombs themselves.
You were there when Potema was summoned. Being at the summoning created a connection to Potema, you are the one to stop her from returning to the living. I can provide you with some help with her minions.
As to Potema herself, find what's left of her body, likely a skeleton. Remove it from the Catacombs and bring it back to be sanctified by Arkay."

The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to acquire the materials necessary to repair the White Phial.
The player should first 1) get unmelting snow, 2) get mammoth tusk powder, 3) get a briar heart to complete their objective. These tasks can be completed in the following locations: 1) Throat of the World(a mountain, on the top), 2) giant camps, 3) Forsworn camps in the Reach.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: White Phial (a legendary bottle that will replenish whatever fluid is placed inside of it).
The following characters are related to this quest: Nurelion (Quintus Navale's master).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Quintus Navale has thought about repairing the White Phial. Nurelion was obsessed with the White Phial: his obsession consumed him.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"I have some thoughts about repairing the White Phial. There are three crucial elements. Some may be easier to find than others.
On the top of the Throat of the World is a patch of unmelting snow. No heat can touch it. Then we need the tusk of a mammoth, ground to a fine powder as only the giants know how. The final step is tricky. It requires the briar heart from a Forsworn of the Reach.
If you can bring me these materials, the Phial can again be made whole. You can keep the White Phial after I have repaired it. I fear keeping the Phial would just remind me of Nurelion's obsession, and how it consumed him."

The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to assassinate the Gourmet, a famous master chef, and get his Writ of Passage to assume his identity.
The player should first question Anton Virane to learn the true identity of the Gourmet, and kill Anton Virane to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: the keep in Markarth.
The following characters are related to this quest: Gourmet (a famous master chef, whose true identity is not known), Astrid (the female guildmaster of the Dark Brotherhood), Anton Virane (a male cook, located at the keep in Markarth).
The following groups are related to this quest: Dark Brotherhood (a guild of assassins).
The following locations are related to this quest: Markarth (a city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Astrid told the player about killing the Gourmet and taking his identity. The player should hide the Gourmet's body if they can.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Let's get down to business. Astrid told you about the Gourmet, I hope? That you need to kill him and take on his identity?
But first you'll need to learn who he is. Assuming, of course, that the Gourmet actually is a "he." Could be a woman for all we know. In my, um, investigations, I came upon this. It's a copy of the Gourmet's cookbook. Ah, but not just any copy. It's signed you see! Seems to be a message from the Gourmet to one Anton Virane. I've tracked Virane to the keep in Markarth. It would seem he's the cook.
You are to obtain that information from Virane - who the Gourmet really is, and where he can be found. Oh, and when you're done with Virane, kill him. Loose ends and all that.
As I was saying... You'll need to kill the Gourmet, of course. But what's more, you'll need to get his Writ of Passage, so you can take his place. Oh, and if you can, hide his body. The longer it takes for anyone else to determine his real identity, the better.
Now off with you!"

The following groups are related to this quest: Thalmor (an elven organization that denies the godhood of Talos and tries to root put Talos worship).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player asked Ondolemar what he is doing in Markarth. Ondolemar knows that Ogmund the Skald worships Talos in his home: the Jarl of Markarth refuses to arrest Ogmund the Skald.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"I was sent here to lead the Thalmor's interests in this corner of the world. It's my mission to root out all Talos worship in this city.
You're awfully inquisitive, aren't you? I like that. Perhaps you'd care to solve a little problem I'm having? Ogmund the Skald. He's old, respected, and I know for a fact that he worships Talos in his home. But the Jarl has been hesitant to call for his arrest. I want you to break in to his home and find evidence."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Endon. Endon is a silversmith, who is located at Markarth.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to recover Endon's stolen silver mold for him.
The player should first find Endon's stolen silver mold to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Pinewatch, a small cottage, and a bandit hideout.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Endon will pay the player well, Endon becomes an ally to the Thieves Guild.
The following characters are related to this quest: Rigel Strong-Arm (a male bandit).
The following groups are related to this quest: Thieves Guild (a guild of thieves rising in power in Markarth).
The following locations are related to this quest: Markarth (a city), Valenwood (a distant province).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player is a member of the Thieves Guild. Endon ordered a silver mold from Valenwood: it was stolen by a group of bandits led by Rigel Strong-Arm. The authorities told Endon that their resources were spread too thin right now.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Several months ago I ordered a special silver mold from some artisans in Valenwood. Well, it never arrived. Later I found out that it was robbed by a group of bandits led by someone named Rigel Strong-Arm.
Look, I talked to everyone with an ounce of authority... everyone. They all told me their resources were spread too thin right now. Word on the street says that the Thieves Guild is coming back into its own in Markarth so I figured... ...to send a thief to steal back what was stolen.
Look, this mold is irreplaceable. I'll pay you well for its return and I can also prove to be quite a valuable ally to the Thieves Guild.  The only thing I can tell you is that the mold was taken to the bandit's hideout... a small cottage called Pinewatch.
I'm not sure how many men they have inside, but I trust that won't be an issue for you. Good luck."

The player should first get a special Hagraven's head with Farkas to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: the place that is already known to the player.
The following characters are related to this quest: Kodlak (the dead male leader of the Companions, who was cured of lycanthropy), Aela (a female member of the Companions).
The following groups are related to this quest: Companions (a band of honorable warriors), Nords (a race of people).
The following locations are related to this quest: Sovngarde (the storied underworld of the Nords).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Kodlak said that werewolves can't be good Nords. Aela said a Hagraven's head is needed to cure lycanthropy.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"There is always work. My mind is someplace else, though.
I think that maybe Kodlak was right. As a werewolf, I can't be a good Nord. I want to be clean, like he was, and go to Sovngarde when I finally die.
Aela said we would need a Hagraven's head. I already have one of them, but she said it was a special kind. And that you knew where to get more.
Let's go find one!"

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Eisa Blackthorn. Eisa Blackthorn is a bandit from Kyr's gang, giving quest via "Eisa's Journal", who is located at Frostmere Crypt.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to Find out what happened in Frostmere Crypt.
The player should first go deeper into Frostmere Crypt to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Frostmere Crypt, a crypt that contains a whole forest with a big old monument out in the center.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Pale Blade (a sword from Frostmere Crypt).
The following characters are related to this quest: Kyr (a male bandit leader, located at Frostmere Crypt), Ra'jirr (a tough male bandit, located at Frostmere Crypt), Pale Lady (a swamp lady who abducts children at night, located at Frostmere Crypt).
The following items are related to this quest: "Eisa's Journal" (Eisa Blackthorn's journal).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Kyr's bandit gang dug up Frostmere Crypt: Kyr took the Pale Blade from the monument within. Ra'jirr keeps muttering about a Pale Lady, who is going to kill all of Kyr's bandits if they do not return the Pale Blade.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Eisa's Journal
by Eisa Blackthorn

Night shift woke me to say they'd hit something big. Kyr, Ra'jirr, and I went down to take a look. It's huge, like a whole forest was just swallowed up by the earth, with a big old monument out in the center. Kyr took a sword from the monument as a trophy and dubbed it the "Pale Blade", proof his whole plan was finally paying off. For once, he might be right.

Ra'jirr's been having nightmares over the past few days. He keeps muttering about a "Pale Lady" - one of those swamp women who steal children away at night, I think. To think some fool story could turn the toughest bandit I know into a cowering kitten, frightened of his own shadow. I'm just glad none of the others see him like this.

It's getting worse. Ra'jirr can barely sleep at all now, and whenever he dozes off, he wakes up screaming - woke the whole place last night. He says the "Pale Lady" is coming for us - she's down in the forest, we have to return the sword or she'll kill us all. Not a chance - the boss clings to that thing like he was born with it. I've told everyone Ra'jirr just has a fever, but this can't go on. I've pulled a few things together. I'll slip out tonight and never look back."
<|endoftext|>

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

The player should first locate enchanted artifacts for Arniel Gane to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Saarthal, an ancient tomb.

The following groups are related to this quest: College of Winterhold (a prestigious school for mages).
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"We are looking for anything at all that might be of interest. That's why I adore Saarthal... we have no idea what we're going to find. And if, along the way, my message about the dangers of magic should happen to sink in for a few students, that would be a happy coincidence.
Hmm. Well, why don't you see if you can assist Arniel Gane? He's one of our scholars, here working on cataloging our finds.
I expect he'd appreciate some help in locating any additional magical artifacts here in the ruins. Any enchanted items will do; the usefulness of the enchantment is irrelevant. If you find anything, the class can look it over."

There are some important facts concerning this quest. Vaermina has an awful hunger for people's memories: in return, she leaves behind nightmares.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"The entire town is being plagued by horrible nightmares. They're in serious danger but I'm afraid there's little I can do about it.
These dreams are manifestations created by Vaermina. She has an awful hunger for our memories. In return, she leaves behind nightmares, not unlike a cough marks a serious illness. I must end her terrible influence over these people before the damage becomes permanent.
I need to return to the source of the problem, to Nightcaller Temple. Perhaps you'd be willing to assist me in that regard? I've already said too much. If anyone overhears what we're saying, it could start a panic. I would simply ask that you trust me and help me end Dawnstar's nightmares.
Nightcaller Temple is only a short walk from Dawnstar. Come, we must hurry."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Dexion Evicus. Dexion Evicus is a moth priest.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to read "Blood".
The player should first perform the ritual of the Ancestor Moth to gain the second sight needed to decipher the Elder Scrolls to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: an Ancestor Glade in Skyrim, in the pine forest.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: the answers the player seeks.
The following items are related to this quest: "Blood" (an Elder Scroll which foreshadows the defiance of the gods with the blood of mortals), Elder Scrolls (mysterious scrolls which are fragments of creation from outside time and space).
The following groups are related to this quest: Ancestor Moths (moths that provide the player with the second sight needed to decipher the Elder Scrolls).
The following locations are related to this quest: Ancestor Glades (secluded locations scattered across Tamriel), Tamriel (a continent), Skyrim (a province on Tamriel).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The ritual of the Ancestor Moth: the player must remove the bark from a canticle tree with a draw knife to attract Ancestor Moths to them.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Scattered across Tamriel are secluded locations known only as Ancestor Glades. There's one in Skyrim, in the Pine Forest.
Performing the Ritual of the Ancestor Moth within the glade should provide the answers you seek. It involves carefully removing the bark from a Canticle Tree which will in turn attract Ancestor Moths to you.
In keeping with tradition, you must use a specific tool in the Ancestor Glade, an implement known as a Draw Knife. Every Moth Priest is taught this ritual, but few ever get the chance to perform it... you should consider yourself fortunate if it works for you.
Once enough of the moths are following, they'll provide you with the second sight needed to decipher the Elder Scrolls. From what I saw in the vision, the Elder Scroll which foreshadows the defiance of the gods with the blood of mortals is the key to the prophecy."

"I have a buyer with a very odd taste in literature, looking for some particular books.
I'm told they're the ravings of a madman, a wizard named Arondil, and his peculiar cravings. It's said to be in four volumes and very hard to come by. My client is offering quite a reward for them, which I'd split with you.
Recently, a woman was found... naked and shivering along the road to Dawnstar. The only information the guard could get from her were tales of strange experiments and Arondil scribbling in his journals.
He used to have a home in Dawnstar until they burned it down. The people say he was doing unspeakable experiments on reanimation... rituals only a necromancer would perform. After he made for Yngvild, he was never heard from again.
In his later years, Arondil moved into some ice caves known as Yngvild. He preferred the solitude in which to perform his, um... experiments."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Astrid. Astrid is the player's guildleader in the Dark Brotherhood.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to lure Titus Mede II to Skyrim so that the Dark Brotherhood can assassinate him.
The player should first assassinate Vittoria Vici at her own wedding to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Temple of the Divines, a large temple in Solitude.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: a significant bonus if the player kills Vittoria Vici while she addresses the wedding guests.
The following characters are related to this quest: Titus Mede II (the Emperor), Vittoria Vici (the overseer of the the East Empire Company's business holdings in Solitude, and the first cousin of the Emperor, located at Temple of the Divines), Night Mother (the female spirit who guides the Dark Brotherhood).
The following groups are related to this quest: Dark Brotherhood (a guild of assassins), Stormcloaks (rebel forces opposing the Empire), East Empire Company (a merchant house).
The following locations are related to this quest: Solitude (a city), Skyrim (a province of the Empire).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The Night Mother spoke to the player. Vittoria Vici has Imperial connections, and her husband has ties to the Stormcloaks: their marriage is a step toward reconciliation between the Empire and the Stormcloaks, but a murder at the wedding will stall the peace process and send shockwaves throughout the entire Empire.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Splendid. We're ready to begin. Or, more specifically, you're ready to begin. After all, you're the one the Night Mother spoke to.
Now then. I hope you have something nice to wear. Because you're going to a wedding. Well, more like the public reception. It should be a lovely affair. You'll mingle with the guests, eat some cake... stab the bride.
Oh yes. You've got to kill the bride. At her wedding. And they say romance is dead. Your target's name is Vittoria Vici. She oversees the East Empire Company's business holdings in Solitude. The wedding is being held in that city, at the Temple of the Divines. Her death will cause an uproar, which is exactly what we want.
Vittoria Vici is the first cousin to our dear Emperor, Titus Mede II. Vici has obvious Imperial connections. Her husband has ties to the Stormcloaks. Their union is a step toward reconciliation. So if there's a murder at the wedding... Not only will it stall the peace process - it will send shockwaves throughout the entire Empire. The Emperor's hand will be forced. He'll have to travel to Skyrim to deal with the aftermath... and he'll find the Dark Brotherhood waiting.
Vici is likely to address her guests frequently, as is the wedding custom. Kill her when she does that, and I promise you a significant bonus.
Now go. And give the city of Solitude a celebration they're not likely to forget."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to return to Falion with a filled black soul gem, and he will perform a vampirism cure ritual.
The player should first get a black soul gem, and fill it by killing someone to complete their objective.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: the player's vampirism will be cured.
The following characters are related to this quest: Agni (a young girl, and Falion's ward).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player is a vampire. Falion has considered becoming a vampire himself, but that would endanger Agni.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"I know many things. I have studied things beyond the reach of most humans, traveled the other planes, seen things one should not see.
I have met gods and long-dead races of people and everything in between and I know enough to see a vampire where others would see a man. I met several of your kind during my studies of life-extending magics. I even considered becoming a vampire myself. In the end, vampirism would endanger my ward Agni which would defeat the intended purpose.
It is possible to cure vampirism. I know of a ritual but I've never performed it. It requires a filled black soul gem. You will need to kill someone. When you have a gem and have filled it return to me and I will perform the ritual. I will bring life to your dead body, vampire."

While he regains strength, however, I am fading. By now I can barely contain his power, much less defeat him if he awakens. But with the help of a living champion I may be able to succeed.
Three vessels in the tomb below hold the power to vanquish Hevnoraak. Before anything else, we need those. Bring them to me - but be careful, mortal. They are guarded by Hevnoraak's minions. They will stop at nothing to see their master return."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Vex. Vex is the player's passive-aggressive superior in the Thieves Guild.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to make reparations for breaking the Thieves Guild rules.
The player should first pay 1,000 gold to Vex for readmittance to the Thieves Guild to complete their objective.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: restored membership of the Thieves Guild.
The following groups are related to this quest: Thieves Guild (a guild of thieves).
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"I'm going to make this short and sweet, because frankly I don't think you deserve another shot. You've broken the rules and now you need to pay... and it's going to cost you quite a bit: 1,000 gold.
You claim to be a thief... act like one. Pick pockets, knock over houses... heck, I don't care if you have to bust into a palace. You do what you have to do to come up with the coin.
Anything you steal, you bring it straight to me. Now get out of here and don't come back until your pockets are full. Only then you're one of us again."
<|endoftext|>

The quest-giver is called Neloth. Neloth is a wizard.

The player should first let Neloth cast a new kind of silence spell on you to complete their objective.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Neloth will prepare a version of the silence spell that the player can cast themselves.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"You could help me with my research. I believe I've discovered a new form of silence. Some philosophers postulate seven orders of silence, but I believe there's an eighth.
If you allow me, I'd like to envelop you in the eighth form, to study the mental effects. If this works, I'll prepare a version that you can cast yourself, if you ever wish to inflict... er, study silence."

Return my father's shield to me and I'll grant you permission to purchase property in my city.
Divines watch over you."

I found the ring's resting place, Shrouded Grove, after he died, but I'm far too old to go exploring some cave, now. I'd be happy to give you some alchemy training in exchange for the ring, if you bring it to me."

The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: the blessing of Dibella.
The following characters are related to this quest: Sybil (a mortal woman who proclaims the will of Dibella), Dibella (the goddess of love and passion).

There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player breached the inner sanctum of the Temple of Dibella and interrupted the Exalted Protocol of the Dibellan Sybil.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"You have committed a breach, and must pay the penalty. Normally, a quick death would be required. Luckily for you, there are more pressing matters.
The ceremony you so rudely interrupted was the Exalted Protocol of the Dibellan Sybil. I don't expect you to know what that means. Suffice to say that our Sybil was recently lost to us. Through the ceremony, we have seen the home of the next Sybil, to the north, in a small village pressed against the stone.
If you can travel there, and retrieve our young Sybil, your transgression will be forgiven. We believe the place in our vision to be Karthwasten. Now move quickly. The girl must be brought to the temple as soon as possible.
You, my dear, can earn the blessing of Dibella as your reward."

The player should first free Odahviing to complete their objective.

The following locations are related to this quest: Dragonsreach (a trap for dragons), Skuldafn (Alduin's door to Sovngarde, an ancient fane high in the eastern mountains filled with Alduin's remaining forces), Sovngarde (the storied underworld where the souls of mortal heroes end up in).

"It was you that lured me here and took me prisoner... I have done nothing to earn your distrust.
Wisdom sees the doorway. It would be wise to recognize when you only have one choice. You can trust me. I am not treacherous. Alduin has proven himself unworthy to rule. I go my own way now. He has traveled to Sovngarde to regain his strength, devouring the souls of the mortal dead. A privilege he jealously guards... His door to Sovngarde is at Skuldafn, one of his ancient fanes high in the eastern mountains. I surely do not need to warn you that all his remaining strength is marshaled there.
Free me, and I will carry you to Skuldafn so that you can face Alduin in battle. I warn you, once you've flown the skies, your envy of the dragons will only increase."

The player should first save the priest of Boethiah from imprisonment to complete their objective.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: The Mace of Molag Bal.

"Fool! Did you think Molag Bal, the Lord of Domination, would so easily reward you? What do you see from that little cage? Speak.
You definitely see the spikes of your cage. Sharp, aren't they? This was the last thing many saw before they were sacrificed in my name. But even a god has his enemies, and my rival Boethiah had her priest desecrate it. So long since it's tasted blood. Until you came.
I want submission. I want the priest who did this to bend his knee and give me his soul. He comes by to perform Boethiah's insulting rites at my altar, but he's been missing. Captured and bound. Left to rot.
You'll get the freedom your kind enjoys so much. Save the priest. Let him perform his rite one more time. And when he does, we will be waiting for him.
Then you will be finally rewarded. The Mace of Molag Bal! I give you its true power, mortal. When your enemies lie broken and bloody before you, know that I will be watching."

I can get you into one of those parties. Once you're inside the Embassy, you get away and find Elenwen's secret files. I have a contact inside the Embassy. He's not up for this kind of high-risk mission, but he can help you. His name's Malborn. Wood elf, plenty of reason to hate the Thalmor. You can trust him.
I'll get word for him to meet you in Solitude, at the Winking Skeever -- you know it? While you're doing that, I'll work on getting you an invitation to Elenwen's little party.
Meet me at the Solitude stables after you've arranged things with Malborn."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Dagur. Dagur is an innkeeper, who is located at Dagur's inn.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to find Isabelle Rolaine.
The player should first talk to Vex about Isabelle Rolaine to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Riften, a city.
The following characters are related to this quest: Isabelle Rolaine (a young, beautiful woman, and Ranmir's lost love), Ranmir (a male drunk who used to be happy with Isabelle Rolaine, located at Dagur's inn), Vex (a woman, located at Riften).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Ranmir is sure that Isabelle Rolaine ran away with Vex.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"I'm Dagur, an innkeeper.
I wondered if I could ask a favor of you. It's about Ranmir. Don't get me wrong, I don't have a problem with him being in my inn all the time. He mostly keeps to himself, and so far he's been able to pay. I just hate to see what's happened to him. He hasn't always been like this, you know. Drunk, I mean.
He was a different person. Happy, outgoing... Like anyone who's in love. See, Ranmir was involved with a pretty young woman named Isabelle Rolaine. The two of them were very happy together, I thought. One day, she just disappeared. Ranmir was convinced she'd run off with someone else, leaving him behind. He turned to drinking, and what's left of him is what you see here every day.
I hoped that maybe if she could be found, if he had some sort of explanation, that maybe he could put himself back together. I'm in no position to go searching for her, but perhaps you could. Ranmir seemed convinced that Isabelle'd run off to Riften with someone named Vex. That's all I remember."
<|endoftext|>

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Phinis Gestor. Phinis Gestor is the player's teacher in conjuration magic.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to learn powerful, new conjuration spells.
The player should first summon an unbound Dremora, prove that you are in control, and order the Dremora bring you a sigil stone from an Oblivion gate to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: the top of the Hall of Attainment.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Phinis Gestor inscribes powerful, new conjuration spells for the player.
The following characters are related to this quest: Dremora (a humanoid creature from the planes of Oblivion).
The following locations are related to this quest: Hall of Attainment (a tall building).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player has advanced quickly in their conjuration studies. Phinis Gestor will teach the player the spell to summon the Dremora, but it will only work in a place properly prepared for the event.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"How quickly you've advanced. Most impressive. There are spells yet to be learned, powerful spells that can more closely and more permanently bind creatures to your will. These spells are difficult, even for one as skilled as I. To even begin to inscribe them, I need something very special. A sigil stone from an Oblivion gate.
I do not have one in my possession. Nor do you, I'm sure. So we require a Dremora to retrieve one for us. You will summon one, and order it to bring a sigil stone to you. I will then inscribe the spells for you.
But there are risks. There are always risks. You must summon and command an unbound Dremora. Summoning an Unbound Dremora is not like other Conjuration spells. It will not simply do your bidding. You must first prove you are in control.
I will teach you the spell to summon the Dremora, but know that it will only work in a place properly prepared for the event. Here is the spell you need. Go to the top of the Hall of Attainment; I have prepared a place for you there."
<|endoftext|>

There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player is married: it presents difficulties for vampires. Vampirism is the greatest gift that vampires can bestow to their loved ones.

"It's come to my inescapable attention that you, my dear friend, are married. Marriage is a fine institution, however, one that does present certain difficulties for such as like ourselves.
May I strongly suggest that you make a visit to this spouse of yours and "invite" her to the family by offering her the Gift of Vampirism. Put her mind to rest, allay her fear through vampiric seduction and when she is in a pliant condition, embrace her and bite her on the neck.
It is the greatest token we can bestow upon those we love and wish to see protected."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is a worshiper of Boethiah.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to get a glimpse of Boethiah.
The player should first gain someone's trust, lead him to the shrine above, instruct him to touch the pillar of sacrifice to trap him, and kill him with the ceremonial blade to complete their objective.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Boethiah will appear before the player.
The following characters are related to this quest: Boethiah (the lady of plots and the dark warrior, an evil goddess).
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"We are forged by Boethiah's example. We carve our will upon the world through our tongues and our blades. You? You are nothing. An empty vapor, dispersed by the slightest breeze.
If you desire a glimpse of Boethiah, our Dark Mistress, then this is what you must do. First, prove your tongue can wield a lie. Find someone. Gain his trust. Lead him to the shrine above. Next, instruct your thrall to touch the Pillar of Sacrifice. Its magic will ensnare him, rendering him helpless. Then, girded with certitude, plant the ceremonial blade deeply, so that the waters of his heart wash over you.
If your will is strong enough, it will stir Boethiah in her Dark Mansion, and she will appear before us."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Arngeir. Arngeir is a wise, old man.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to find a lost word of power.
The player should first get to the location marked on your map to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Skyrim, a province with many words of power.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: the player learns a new word of power.
The following characters are related to this quest: Dragonborn (a mortal blessed with the blood and soul of a dragon, masters of the Thu'um).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player is the Dragonborn.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"You have learned so much already, Dragonborn. Growing your gift too quickly would be dangerous.
But there are many Words of Power in Skyrim, carved in the Dragon tongue. Even from here, we can feel the Thu'um resonate from them. Finding these lost Words would be a sufficient test, to temper your abilities with experience.
We have felt the whisper of a Word. Give me your map, and I will show you where its echo can be found."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Jaree-Ra. Jaree-Ra is a treasure hunter, who is located at Solitude Docks.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to help run the Icerunner aground.
The player should first 1) put out the lighthouse fire, 2) meet Jaree-Ra to complete their objective. These tasks can be completed in the following locations: 1) Solitude Lighthouse(a lighthouse in Solitude), 2) Solitude Docks(the docks in Solitude).
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: loot from the Icerunner.
The following characters are related to this quest: Deeja (Jaree-Ra's sister, a female treasure hunter).
The following locations are related to this quest: Icerunner (a cargo ship), Solitude (a city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Jaree-Ra and Deeja collect things nobody misses. With the war, many more ships come through Solitude Docks loaded with weapons and pay, but few people.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"It's easy to find things to sell. Things nobody will miss. Things from underground, or just left lying around in someone's house. I bet the two of us, we're very alike. So why not take the next step? We can help each other.
My sister Deeja and I are treasure hunters. You could be too. We like to collect things. We are not thieves. We just take what will not be missed. What no one needs anymore. Maybe we take some weapons and stop a few deaths. Who would call that thievery?
With the war, many more ships come through these docks. Loaded with weapons and pay, but few people. And they pass through dangerous waters. We have an interest in one of those boats, the Icerunner. The Solitude Lighthouse will be guiding it in... but if its fire were to go out, the Icerunner would run aground.
If someone were to put out the lighthouse fire and then meet me on the docks afterwards... I could certainly direct them to that loot. That someone could be you."

The following locations are related to this quest: Skyrim (a province).

Now that I have reclaimed one of my Elder Scrolls, we must find a Moth Priest to read it. I have spread false rumors about the discovery of an Elder Scroll in Skyrim to lure a Moth Priest here. Now it is time to see if those efforts have borne fruit.
Go forth, and search the land for rumors of a Moth Priest within our borders. Look to the cities. Speak to innkeepers, carriage drivers, anyone who would meet a traveler.
Go now, and carry out this task. This is my command!"

There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player asked Kesh the Clean about speaking with Peryite. Deathbell grow in the frozen tundra. The player might find the ruby and silver in a mine. Vampire dust comes from vampires.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Not everyone has the stomach required to entreat my Lord. He is the pus in the wound. Oh, proper ones curl their noses, but it's pus that drinks foul humors and restores the blood. But Kesh likes you, friend.
There is a way Peryite may speak to us who will take Him in. If you wish to commune with Him, we'll need the incense. Fetch for me a deathbell flower, one silver ingot, a flawless ruby, and some vampire dust. Then I will show you how.
How to gather the ingredients? This one would try a shop. You might prefer the direct route, hm? Deathbell grow in the frozen tundra. You might nip into a mine for the ruby and silver. Vampire Dust is tricky. Vampires, you know."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Daynas Valen. Daynas Valen is a historian, giving quest via "Daynas Valen's Notes".
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to investigate the forgotten legend of Gauldur, and find the 3 pieces of the Gauldur Amulet.
The player should first 1) find Mikrul's amulet piece, 2) find Jyrik's amulet piece, 3) find Sigdis' amulet piece to complete their objective. These tasks can be completed in the following locations: 1) Folgunthur(the ancient barrows at the foot of Solitude), 2) Saarthal(ancient, shattered, half-buried crypts), 3) Geirmund's Hall(a tomb).
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Gauldur Amulet (a powerful amulet that belonged to Archmage Gauldur).
The following characters are related to this quest: Archmage Gauldur (a man revered throughout the north for his wisdom, wealth, honor, and power, who lived during the first era), Mikrul (the youngest of Archmage Gauldur's three sons), Jyrik (the oldest of Archmage Gauldur's three sons), Sigdis (the middle child of Archmage Gauldur's three sons), Archmage Geirmund (a tough male wizard).
The following items are related to this quest: "Daynas Valen's Notes" (Daynas Valen's research notes).
The following locations are related to this quest: Solitude (a city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The Gauldur name wiped out from the annals of history. Mikrul, Jyrik, and Sigdis lusted after Archmage Gauldur's power and prestige: they discovered Archmage Gauldur's source of power, the Gauldur Amulet. Archmage Gauldur was murdered by his sons Mikrul, Jyrik, and Sigdis: they split the Gauldur Amulet between them. Mikrul, Jyrik, and Sigdis laid waste to surrounding villages: the high king sent Archmage Geirmund and his battlemages after Mikrul, Jyrik, and Sigdis.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Daynas Valen's Notes
by Daynas Valen

How to summarize a lifetime of research? So little of what I have learned matters now - the petty politics of ancient times, the age-long campaign to wipe out all mention of the Gauldur name.
In the opening days of the First Era, the Archmage Gauldur was revered throughout the north. Wisdom, wealth, honor, and power were his, and even the legendary heros' heirs sought his counsel.
Smothered by his shadow, Gauldur's three sons grew cruel and resentful. They lusted after their father's power and prestige, and eventually Jyrik, the eldest, discovered its source: a mysterious amulet, from which he never parted. Together, they conspired to murder their father in his sleep and divide his amulet between them. And so it was done.
Consumed by their newfound power, the brothers laid waste to the surrounding villages. So great was the carnage that the High King himself intervened, sending a company of battlemages led by the Archmage Geirmund to subdue the brothers. And after a devastating battle, the three fled the field.
Mikrul, the youngest, was run to ground in Folgunthur, the ancient barrows at the foot of Solitude. Geirmund pursued Jyrik to the shattered crypts of Saarthal, half-buried even then. And at last, Sigdis was cornered in the southernmost reaches of land and later entombed in Geirmund's Hall."
<|endoftext|>

The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: things Roggi pawned to Iddra.

The following groups are related to this quest: Nord (a race of stubborn people).
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Roggi has been in Kynesgrove forever. Great storyteller. Keeps everyone's spirits up. Owes me a lot of coin for drinks. I keep telling him not to worry about it, but he's got the stubborn Nord blood.
Damn fool doesn't have the coin to pay me back, so he just beats himself up over it, and then he gets thirsty, and it cycles all over again. If you could convince him that I don't care about his tab, it'd certainly make me feel better.
Roggi pawned a few of his things back when he still had things to pawn. Take them as your reward."

"They found it! They actually found Rjorn's drum!
You don't know who Rjorn is? You're joking, right? Rjorn? Only the most famous battle drummer of the second age. Well, famous among bards at least. That drum has been in half a dozen famous battles. It's a priceless artifact.
Nobody knows where he died, and therefore where his drum might be. Halldir was the missing link. Rjorn was always looking for new stories to tell. It seems he was writing a lay about Halldir when he vanished. Rjorn entered Halldir's Cairn in secret, and presumably died there.
Now all I need to do is find someone to get it. Wait. You. You could do it. I need you to get me that drum. The college treasury is a bit thin right now. But I can show you some tricks I learned from my days with the army."

The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Mara's gift.
The following characters are related to this quest: Mara (the goddess of love).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Keep away from the keep and the city guards: they won't accept the missives.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Riften is drowning in a sea of sin and wickedness and it's my personal mission to let everyone know that the warmth of Mara can see them through.
All I need is a messenger to bring Her words to these poor souls by distributing these missives. Lady Mara would be so pleased, if you could distribute the missives! Let me give you the missives. Here you are. Now make sure you give out every single one, we can't afford to let even one lost soul stray from Her warmth.
Almost anyone in Riften is in dire need of those missives. Speak to them, child. You will know who will listen and who will sin. A word of advice, keep away from the Keep and the city guards. They follow their own path and have already forsaken Her.
Allow me to give you Mara's gift as a reward... a true blessing to aid you in times of need. Despair not, her warmth will protect you always!"

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Eola. Eola is a female cannibal.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to find your place as a follower of Namira.
The player should first meet Eola and fight your way through the undead with her to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Reachcliff Cave, a tomb filled with undead.
The following characters are related to this quest: Namira, Lady of Decay (the goddess of cannibals).
The following locations are related to this quest: Markarth (a city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Eola assumes that the player is a cannibal. Eola has been eating the dead people of Markarth.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"You were young when you first tasted human flesh, weren't you? A brother or sister had died? An accident, of course.
Then the hunger set in. Curiosity. What's the harm in just one bite? It's okay, now. You've found a friend who understands you. You can let go of your guilt.
A lot of our kind block out the memory of their first meal. The shame is too much. But you don't need to hide anymore. Namira, the Lady of Decay, accepts you for what you are.
She has a place for us, where we can sate our appetites without judgment. It's inside Reachcliff Cave. But the dead have stirred from their slumber recently, and I was forced here. Meet me there. We will fight our way to Namira's embrace together.
Until then, tell the people of Markarth that their dead won't be disturbed, anymore. We have bigger plans ahead."

There are some important facts concerning this quest. Shalidor holed himself up in Labyrinthian, and devoted all of his time to research and study.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Have you ever heard of Shalidor? Immensely powerful mage, back in the First Era. Had an understanding of magic few have ever matched. He holed himself up in Labyrinthian, and devoted all of his time to research and study. Wrote more than you would imagine possible.
Since then, his writings have been scattered all over Skyrim, but are little use to anyone who can't translate them. I'm one of the few who can. I'm always trying to find more of Shalidor's writings.
I've heard whispers of more of his work having turned up. If you can track it down, it may prove useful to all of us."

There are some important facts concerning this quest. Medresi Dran's work force ran away while excavating Angarvunde: they opened a chamber full of undead.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"I'm on the verge of incredible wealth, but my cowardly work force ran at the first sign of danger. We were excavating this old tomb when we opened a chamber full of corpses. The team took one look, turned tail, and ran.
Legend says this tomb holds a treasure that bestows great power on the one who discovers it. Beyond that, not much more is known. Obviously, this treasure will fetch a good deal of gold, and I'm willing to let you share in the reward when we find it.
I'll tell you what. You help me get the treasure and I'll split it with you. First, I need you to clear the main chamber of those restless dead. I'll stay here until you're finished, planning our next move.
With my brains and your brawn, that treasure will soon be mine... uh, ours."

The rings increase the abilities of your vampiric powers. Some say Molag Bal himself gave these rings to ancient powerful vampire lords. Some say that is just a myth.
You'll be able to keep the rings. I wouldn't be telling you where to find them if I desired them for myself."

Actually, there is a way to do this, but I don't think I could get away with doing it. She'd kill me if she found out. You see, I happen to know after she makes love, she gives her partner a token of her affection called a Mark of Dibella. If you confront her with three of the Marks of Dibella, she'd be so embarrassed... well, I don't know what she'd do!
Oh, this is going to be great! You need to get the Marks of Dibella from Bolli, Hofgrir and Indaryn. Not sure how you're going to do that, but try your best. Then just confront Haelga with them and the rest works itself out."

I offer you my blood. Take it, and you will walk as a lion among sheep. Men will tremble at your approach, and you will never fear death again.
However, if you refuse my gift you will be prey, like all mortals. I will spare your life this once, but you will be banished from this hall.
I await your decision."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

The Greybeards think that the player is a Dragonborn: a Dragonborn is said to be uniquely gifted in the voice - the ability to focus the player's vital essence into a Thu'um, or shout.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"So when the dragon died, you absorbed some kind of power from it. So it's true. The Greybeards really were summoning you. They are masters of the Way of the Voice. They live in seclusion high on the slopes of the Throat of the World.
Whatever happened when you killed that dragon, it revealed something in you, and the Greybeards heard it. If they think you're Dragonborn, who are we to argue?
The Dragonborn is said to be uniquely gifted in the Voice - the ability to focus your vital essence into a Thu'um, or Shout. If you really are Dragonborn, they can teach you how to use your gift.
You'd better get up to High Hrothgar immediately. There's no refusing the summons of the Greybeards. It's a tremendous honor."

The following characters are related to this quest: Una (a maid, located at Blue Palace), Erdi (a maid, located at Blue Palace).
The following locations are related to this quest: Pelagius Wing (a forbidden wing of the Blue Palace).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Dervenin's master says that Dervenin is interrupting his vacation. Without Dervenin's master's guidance, Dervenin's homeland is falling apart. Dervenin's master went into the Pelagius Wing to talk with an old friend. Dervenin gives the player a hip bone: the player can't enter Pelagius Wing without it.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"My master has abandoned me! Abandoned his people. And nothing I say can change his mind. Now he refuses to even see me. He says I interrupt his vacation! It's been so many years... Won't you please help?
Without his guidance, our homeland is falling apart. North wages war against the south! We need his return. Oh, but... I'm sure he'll repay you when he comes to his senses! His favor is a powerful, powerful thing. And so very worth any... inconveniences.
Last I saw him, he was visiting a friend in the Blue Palace. But no one as mundane as the local ruler. No, no... such people are below him. No, he went into the forbidden wing of the palace, to speak with an old friend. Said it had been ages since they had last had tea. Oh and you'll need the hip bone... it's very important. No entering Pelagius Wing without that.
The doors to the Pelagius Wing are locked. But I hear the maids, Una and Erdi, know how to enter it for cleaning. Surely they can help for such an important matter?"

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Madanach. Madanach is a Forsworn man, and a prisoner who tried to have the player killed in the past, who is located at Cidhna Mine.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to discover how widespread the injustice of Markarth is.
The player should first talk to Braig: tell him that Madanach sent you, and ask him why he is in Cidhna Mine to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Cidhna Mine, a prison mine.
The player will receive the following rewards for completing the quest objective: Madanach will help the player escape.
The following characters are related to this quest: Braig (a man who has been in Cidhna Mine the longest beside Madanach).
The following groups are related to this quest: Forsworn (an organization that opposes the current rulers of Markarth).
The following locations are related to this quest: Markarth (a city).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. The player has been imprisoned in Cidhna Mine without any reason.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Well, well. Look at you. The authorities of Markarth have turned you into an animal. A wild beast caged up and left to go mad.
So, my fellow beast, what do you want? Answers about the Forsworn? Revenge for trying to have you killed? You're one of us now, you see? A slave. The boot of the false, unjust law stepping on your throat. Maybe if you understood that, I could help you.
There's a man named Braig inside these mines. Besides me, he's been here the longest. Tell him I sent you. Ask him why he's here. I want you to know how widespread the injustice of Markarth is. Then, we might discuss about an early pardon."

"In days past, my brother Torkild and I would share the hunt, but that was... long ago.

Werebears are twisted, cursed beasts. True bears are noble and great creatures of the wild. I've heard tell of men who, by curse or by heart's desire, become transformed into one of those vile things. It is a pitiable fate. And one that I fear has fallen to my brother.
If you happen to cross his path, be wary. He was a fierce warrior as a man. If he fell prey to his more bestial side, he could be deadly."

This is an RPG quest from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.
The quest-giver is called Astrid. Astrid is the player's leader in the Dark Brotherhood, who is located at Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary.
The quest-giver gives a quest to the player. The player's objective is to spy on Cicero and the person he is talking with.
The player should first hide inside the Night Mother's coffin to eavesdrop on the meeting between Cicero and a mystery person to complete their objective. This task can be completed in the following location: Night Mother's Chamber in the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary.
The following characters are related to this quest: Cicero (an insane male member of the Dark Brotherhood, and the Night Mother's Keeper, located at Night Mother's Chamber), Night Mother (the corpse of the spiritual female leader of the Dark Brotherhood, located at Night Mother's Chamber).
The following groups are related to this quest: Dark Brotherhood (a guild of assassins).
There are some important facts concerning this quest. Cicero has been concerning Astrid ever since he arrived at the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary: Astrid thinks that Cicero is plotting to overtake the Dark Brotherhood Sanctuary and restore the Old Ways.
This is the quest description, the quest-giver explaining the quest to the player:
"Cicero concerns me. Ever since he arrived, his behavior's been... Well, erratic would be an understatement. I do believe he is truly mad. But it's worse than that.
Cicero's taken to locking himself in the Night Mother's chamber, and talking. To someone. In hushed, but frantic tones. Who is he speaking with? What are they planning? I fear treachery. As the Night Mother's Keeper, he believes he's entitled to the rule of this Sanctuary. Cicero will cite our independence as the need to revert to the Old Ways. He'll claim we're undisciplined, unruly. Heretical, even. Ironically, the Night Mother could prove to be just as much a victim. The queen in a fool's twisted game of chess.
I need you to steal into that chamber, and eavesdrop on their meeting. It'll be no use clinging to the shadows. They'll see you for sure. No, you need a hiding place. Somewhere they'd never think to look. Like inside the Night Mother's coffin."
